Dear Sir,

Mr. William my co-worker has a diary from 1905 to 1947. Henry and his friend Mr. Henry J. Smith wrote it. It deals generally with farming operations, particularly principally of crops and weather conditions. It is for your benefit I could be of any benefit or to you! forward it or to you!

Henry Ford

It is difficult to prepare a general questionnaire on pioneer life because no individual who is asked to answer it has exactly the same experiences as another. Some of the questions here will not apply to your experiences; others may prove impossible for you to answer, so don't worry about leaving blank spaces. The object of these questions is to get information from those who have lived in this province or its vicinity.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who lived in Western Canada before 1924, and may be answered by anyone who has personal experience of the pioneer years whether born in this province or not.

If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write them on separate sheets or apply for a separate questionnaire.

Other Questionnaires

Saskatchewan Archives Questionnaire No. 1, entitled "Pioneer List: What Did Western Canadian Pioneers Have?" is still being circulated. If you have not already answered this, and would be willing to do so, please put a check mark here (X) and one will be sent to you.

SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRES

No. 2

PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

A word of explanation to the person answering this questionnaire.

It is difficult to prepare a general questionnaire on pioneer life because no individual who is asked to answer it has exactly the same experiences as another. Some of the questions here will not apply to your experiences; others may prove impossible for you to answer, so don't worry about leaving blank spaces. It's better to give details or describe particular events, if they help to answer the questions.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who lived in Western Canada before 1924, and may be answered by anyone who has personal experiences of the pioneer years whether born in this province or not.

If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write them on separate sheets or reply for a separate questionnaire.

Other Questionnaires

Saskatchewan Archives Questionnaire No. 1, entitled Pioneer Diet: What Did Western Canadian Pioneers Eat? is still being circulated. If you have not already answered this and would be willing to do so, please put a check mark here (X).

Saskatchewan Archives questionnaires on other subjects will be prepared at a later date. Some of these are listed below. Please mark the ones you would be willing to answer.

(X) All questionnaires
- Pioneer health conditions

- Pioneer housing
- Pioneer education and churchwork
- Pioneer farming experience

Preservation of Questionnaires

1. Your full name: HARRY FORD

2. Your address: HUMBERDALE, SASK.

3. Date: MAY 27, 1953

4. Where were you born? (Give name of place and country): UTTOXETER, STAFFORDSHIRE, ENGLAND

5. What was your father's name and occupation?: WILLIAM FORD, Railway engine driver

6. When did you come to Saskatchewan? (Give month and year): MAY 1903

7. Mention any other places where you lived before coming to Saskatchewan, giving dates wherever possible:
   - John on farm, England: 1882-1894
   - Nicola, BC: 1894-1903

8. How old were you when you first came to Western Canada? (You do not need to answer this question if you would rather not or you may use "I was a small child", "I was in my teens", etc.): 22

9. What were your reasons for coming West?
   - My employer closed his shop so I came to Canada.

10. How did you learn about the West? (Through other people? Reading about it? Railroad or government information?):
    - Through my employer CHARLES MYCOCK who had been in the Regina district in 1892 and 1893. He informed me they were two very dry years which dried and killed the trees but he was never from there back in 1903 also from government in form also.
1. Your full name: HARRY FORD

2. Your address: HUMBOLDT, SASK.

3. Date: MAY 27, 1953

4. Where were you born? (Give name of place and country): UTTOXETER, STAFFORDSHIRE, ENGLAND

5. What was your father's name and occupation?: WILLIAM FORD, Railway engine driver

6. When did you come to Saskatchewan? (Give month and year): MAY 1903

7. Mention any other places where you lived before coming to Saskatchewan, giving dates wherever possible:
   - LIVERPOOL, ENGLAND: 1882-1894
   - RICHLAND, ENGLAND: 1894-1903

8. How old were you when you first came to Western Canada? (You do not need to answer this question if you would rather not or you may use "I was a small child", "I was in my teens", etc.): 22

9. What were your reasons for coming West? (Through other people? Reading about it? Railroad or government information?):
   - My employer, Charles Mycock, who had been in the N.W.M. district in 1892 and 1893, informed me that the weather was very dry there, which suited him, but he was never back, but he came back in 1903 also from government to form a new government.
11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada?

very critical and said "Why go to a distant land for the need for pioneer for our colonies."

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends or other groups)?

Some relatives and friends

13. What means of transportation did you use?

Boat and Train

14. What incidents of the journey West do you remember? (People you met on the way, meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, accidents or other experiences).

Traveling in Quebec, we actually fell into a river. It was very cold and very icy.

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan?

The emigration trail day in Regina.

16. Where did you settle or take up land?

N.W.T. 20-37-23-W.2nd June 1903.

17. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan.

On farm near Regina. I have spent three months at winter in Vancouver.

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How after you came?

I was a wheelwright in ENGLAND. In the summer I worked as a carpenter in Regina. I have been employed as a driller from 1903 to 1906. Did you homestead during the winter and then farmed continuously until that time?
11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada?

very critical - only my grandparents stood up for me, and said "Well, you're going to have to make a living somewhere."

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends or other groups)?

Some relatives and friends.

13. What means of transportation did you use?

Boat and Train

14. What incidents of the journey West do you remember? (People you met on the way, meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, accidents or other experiences).

Traveling in Quebec, we walked through the woods very cold. A slightly kinder, who we thought was very courteous, quickly turned.

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan?

The immigration building in Regina.

16. Where did you settle or take up land in Saskatchewan?

Macleod homesteaded early on near the old St. Homestead.

17. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan.

On farm occupation, I have spent three months at work in Vancouver.

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How after you came?

I was a wheelwright in England and the summer worked on a cowboy. Did not homestead during from 1903 to 1906. Did own farmed continuously in the winter and claim farmed continuously until that time.
11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada? They thought it was a very good idea.

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends or other group)? I traveled with some relatives and friends.

13. What means of transportation did you use? Boat and Train

14. What incidents of the journey west do you remember? (People you met on the way, meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, accidents or other excitement etc.) Landing in Quebec, we eagerly fell on the land of a steady friend who we thought very generous.

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan? The emigration trail day in Regina.

16. Where did you settle or take up land? Made homestead only on No. 20-37-23 W2 in June 1903.

17. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan. On four occasions I have spent three months or winter in Vancouver.

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How after you came? I was a wheelwright in England in the summer. Worked as a carpenter in Regina in the fall and during the winter from 1903 to 1906. Did my homestead duties in the winter and then farmed continuously until that time.
11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada? They thought it was a good idea.

12. Did you need for passage for our children? Yes, we needed tickets for our children.

13. What means of transportation did you use? Boat and Train

14. What incidents of the journey West do you remember? (People you met on the way, meetings with Indians, adventures or other excitement etc.)

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan? The emigration trail along in Regina.

16. Where did you settle or take up land? Made homestead only on No. 20-37-23 W. 2nd June 1903.

17. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan. On four occasions I have visited three months each winter in Winnipeg.

18. How did you make a living in Western Canada? How about you family? I was a wheelwright in England. In the summer I worked as a carpenter in Regina. I then moved to Calgary from 1903 to 1906. I did my farming autobiography in the winter and then farmed continuously until present time.
19. How often did you write to relatives or friends in your old home?

20. If you got married, give the name of your husband or wife along with the date and place of marriage.

HELENA. Jan. 16th, 1904. Humboldt.

21. Did anyone else come to Saskatchewan because of your recommending it as a place to settle?

Yes, I brought my sisters with me.

22. If other members of your family (brothers, sisters, parents, etc.) came West tell when they came and where they settled.

WILLIAM. 1912. HUMBOLDT CITY. SASK.

EMMA. 1916. STAR CITY. SASK.

HANNAH. 1916. NEW WESTMINSTER. B.C.

LIZZIE. 1916. CLAIR. SASK.

23. Is there any particular experience of pioneer days that stands out in your memory which you would like to record?

In October 1904, I shipped in with a team of horses from Regina. We took eleven days to make the trip and my friend and I slept under the stars no trouble. The company was only five kilometres run out of town. However, and the harnesses were good and tough.

24. Did you travel about much in the early years? (For business, attending church, visiting friends, etc.)

Refuse to Question 27. Generally traveled to Regina from 1903 to 1906 about three times a year or fourteen times a year. The first two years the distance was seven miles away. Travel was by horse away only thirty-four times a year. But mostly over.
19. How often did you write to relatives or friends in your old home?

20. If you got married, give the name of your husband or wife along with the date and place of marriage.

HELENA. Jan. 16th, 1909. Hamilton

21. Did anyone else come to Saskatchewan because of your recommendation it as a place to settle?

Yes. I thought it was a good place.

22. If other members of your family (brothers, sisters, parents, etc.) came West tell when they came and where they settled.

WILLIAM. 1912. HUMBOLT COUNTY, SASK.

EMMA. 1916. STAR CITY, SASK.

HANNAH. 1916. NEW WESTMINSTER, B.C.

LIZZIE. 1916. CLAIR, SASK.

23. Is there any particular experience of pioneer days that stands out in your memory which you would like to record?

In October 1904, I helped my wife a lot of times from Regina. We took eleven days to make the trip and my friend and I slept under the stars no trouble. The compass our only guide. New out of treachery. How dear and lonely were good and tough.

24. Did you travel about much in the early years? (For business, attending church, visiting friends, etc.) How often?

Refuse to question. Generally traveled to Regina from 1905 to 1906 about three times a year or sometimes no travel. The train was seen in 10 miles. Bought 7 mile away. Travel was by horse away only 3 or 4 times a year. And mostly over.
19. How often did you write to relatives or friends in your old home?

20. If you got married, give the name of your husband or wife along with the date and place of marriage.

HELENA. Jan. 16th, 1909.

21. Did anyone else come to Saskatchewan because of your recommendation as a place to settle?

Jen. I thought of this winter

22. If other members of your family (brothers, sisters, parents, etc.) came West tell when they came and where they settled.

WILLIAM. 1912. HUMBOLDT. SASK.
EMMA. 1916. STAR CITY. SASK.
HANNAH. 1916. NEW WESTMINSTER. B.C.
LIZZIE. 1916. CLAIR. SASK.

23. Is there any particular experience of pioneer days that stands out in your memory which you would like to record?

In October 1904, I traveled in with a team of horses from Regina. It took eleven days to make the trip and my friend and I slept under the stars. No tents. The compass was only of the common kind. An old blanket, powder and the team were our goods and enough.

24. Did you travel about much in the early years? (For business, attending church, visiting friends, etc.)

Ref. to question 27. Generally traveled to Regina once a year. Also from 1903 to 1906 about three times a year. In business no travel. The first two years in town was 10 miles church 7 miles away. Friends were seen by driving away only 3 or 4 times a year. Travel was by horse and mostly over.
19. How often did you write to relatives or friends in your old home?

20. If you got married, give the name of your husband or wife along with the date and place of marriage.

HELENA. Jan. 16th 1909.

21. Did anyone else come to Saskatchewan because of your recommendation it as a place to settle?

Yes, I thought and knew it was.

22. If other members of your family (brothers, sisters, parents, etc.) came West tell when they came and where they settled.

WILLIAM. 1912. HUMBOLDT CITY. SASK.

EMMA. 1916. STAR CITY. SASK.

HANNON. 1916. NEW WESTMINSTER. B.C.

LILLIE. 1916. CLAIR. SASK.

23. In the early particular experience of pioneer days that stand out in your memory which took place in your life?

In October 1904, I arrived in what was then called the city from Regina. It took eleven days to make the trip and my friend and I slept under the stars no tents. The company was only six members and we ran out of barley flour and our supplies were gone and tough.

24. Did you travel about much in the early years? (for business, attending church, visiting friends, etc.) How often? How far?

Referring to Question 27, I usually traveled to Regina from 1903 to 1906 about three times a year in business, no church. At that time there was only one church seven miles away, friends were seen by horse away only once or twice a year. Travel was by horse and mostly oxen.
25. When was the first car used in the community?  
1910

26. If you owned a car before 1914, when did you buy it? What make?  

27. Where was your traveling center? How far from your home?  
No place

28. Did you continue to travel there? (Indicate any changes due to new towns appearing, better means of travel, etc.)  
No. Hardball built up 5 miles away. Still the same method of travelling.

29. How often did you shop in the early days?  
The men shopped once a month. The ladies only once during the winter.

30. When (if ever) did people in your district first start going to town regularly on Saturdays?  
About 1920

31. When (if ever) did you first begin to buy through the mail order catalogue?  
What kind of articles did you buy in this way? Indicate also what fraction of your total purchases were by mail order and any changes in the proportion of purchases made by mail order since the year reported.

32. When did you first have a telephone and what company provided it?  
Golden Ace Telephone Co.

33. When you came to Saskatchewan the first time was it with the idea of staying permanently? Or did you make up your mind after trying it out? When did you make this decision?  
I came with the intention of staying.

28. Did you continue to trade there? (Indicate any changes due to new towns appear-

ing, better means of travel, etc.)

No. Humboldt built up 5 miles away.

Still the same method of travelling.

The men bought once a month only once during the winter.

About 1920

What kind of articles did you buy in this way? Indicate also what fraction of your total purchases were by mail order and any charges for the property purchased by mail order since the beginning.

Stores and goods etc. for about 1914.

In general not much change.

32. When did you first have a telephone and what company operated it?

1917. Golden Area Telephone Co.

33. When you came to Saskatchewan the first time was it with the idea of staying permanently? Or did you make up your mind after trying it out? When did you make this decision?

I came with the intention of staying.
34. Did any people move away from your district prior to 1914? What reasons did they have for moving?

No.

35. Did many people move away during the 1930's? Did many return?

No. This district always had crops.

36. If you or some member of your family have held public office, or have been active in any organizations, mention it here, giving dates wherever possible.

I was an active member of the Green River Association from 1926-1927. I was connected with the United Farmers' Co-operative Credit Union from 1927-1929. I was also connected with the Green River School District from 1918-1926. I was connected with the Humboldt Line Stockmen's Association from 1920-1926. I was connected with the Wheat Pool from 1922-1926, which was dissolved and amalgamated with the Wheat Pool Pool in 1926-1927. I was connected with the Green River Society from 1926-1927. I was connected with the Green River Society from 1926-1927.

My son Stanley was elected to the Board of Directors in 1950.

37. If you or any of your family or friends were "first" to have or do something in the district mention it here giving dates wherever possible. (Such as owning the first automobile, combine, organizing the first lodge, etc.).

Volunteer labor built the first Anglican Church at Dover in 1908, but it was destroyed by a small cyclone in June 1908.

One of the first settlers in 1903 was Henry Mycock who got the location of land by buying white pigs on the wagon wheel and counting his revolutions from the Township office. He was only 400 yards away.

38. How did the places in your community get their names? (School districts, Post Offices, villages, railway stations, creeks, hills, etc.). Dover School named after the surveyor in 1904 by the B.W.R.

Lake Anna named after one of the first women Mrs Anna Mycock whose husband got squatter rights in 1903.
35. Did any people move away during the 1930s? If so, how many?

No.

36. If you or some member of your family have held public office, or have been active in any organization, mention it here giving dates whenever possible.

From 1926-1927, Mr. and Mrs. Ford Harry were members of the Ford Harry Club from 1927-1937. They were members of the Ford Harry Club from 1937-1947.

37. If you or any of your family or friends were actively engaged in anything in the district or nation, it here. Giving dates whenever possible, (such as owning the first automobiles, combining organizing the first league, etc.)

My son, Henry, was a member of the Ford Harry Club from 1947-1952.
